results.title: 3 Teens Charged With Murder in Rock-Throwing Spree That Killed Colorado Driver
results.abstract: Alexa Bartell, 20, was driving in Jefferson County when her Chevrolet Spark was struck by a large rock, the authorities said.

media.caption: Alexa Bartell, 20, was killed on April 19 in Jefferson County, Colo., when a rock was thrown through the windshield of a car she was driving.
media.copyright: The family of Alexa Bartell, via Jefferson County Sheriff’s Office.

results.adx_keywords: Civil Rights Movement (1954-68);Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Deaths (Obituaries);Donham, Carolyn Bryant;Till, Emmett Louis;Mississippi
results.title: Carolyn Bryant Donham Dies at 88; Her Words Doomed Emmett Till
results.abstract: She accused Emmett, 14, of accosting her, and her testimony led to the acquittals of her husband and his half brother in a murder that helped galvanize the civil rights movement.

media.caption: Carolyn Bryant with her husband, Roy Bryant, and their children during his trial in 1955.
media.copyright: Ed Clark/The LIFE Picture Collection, via Shutterstock

results.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Jeremy W. Peters and Michael S. Schmidt
results.title: On Eve of Trial, Discovery of Carlson Texts Set Off Crisis Atop Fox
results.abstract: Private messages sent by Tucker Carlson that had been redacted in legal filings showed him making highly offensive remarks that went beyond the comments of his prime-time show.

media.caption: The discovery of the texts added pressure on the Fox leadership as it sought to find a way to avoid a trial in the Dominion defamation lawsuit.
media.copyright: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Television;Mayors;Politics and Government;Springer, Jerry;Cincinnati (Ohio)
results.title: Jerry Springer, Host of a Raucous TV Talk Show, Is Dead at 79
results.abstract: The confrontational “Jerry Springer Show” ran for nearly three decades and became a cultural phenomenon. Mr. Springer also had a career in politics.

media.caption: Mr. Springer in 1998 on the set of his talk show. That year his viewership peaked at about eight million.

results.adx_keywords: Content Type: Personal Profile;Country Music;Rap and Hip-Hop
results.title: Meet Jelly Roll, the Rapper Turned Country Singer Rousing Nashville
results.abstract: The 38-year-old artist born Jason DeFord has been turning his struggles into music for years. Now it has a bit more twang, and a lot more attention.

media.copyright: Gabriel McCurdy for The New York Times

results.title: How to Claim Your Share of Facebook’s $725 Million Privacy Settlement
results.abstract: Anyone who had a U.S. Facebook account between May 2007 and December 2022 is eligible to apply, though payouts are likely to be small.

media.caption: The offices of Meta, Facebook’s parent company, in Menlo Park, Calif., in 2022.

results.title: Buffalo Remakes its Museum in its Own Image
results.abstract: With a renowned collection of modern and contemporary art, the Buffalo AKG Art Museum has taken local concerns to heart in a $230 million transformation.

results.title: Ed Sheeran Defends Himself in Court, With His Guitar
results.abstract: The pop star strummed a four-chord progression from “Thinking Out Loud” in a Manhattan courtroom, seeking to separate his work from Marvin Gaye’s “Let’s Get It On.”

media.caption: Ed Sheeran, right, testified with a guitar on Thursday at a closely watched copyright trial in Manhattan.
media.copyright: Anna Watts for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Sexual Harassment;Sex Crimes;Doctors;Decisions and Verdicts;Heaps, James;University of California, Los Angeles;Reagan, Ronald, UCLA Medical Center;California;Los Angeles County (Calif)
results.title: Former U.C.L.A. Doctor Is Sentenced to 11 Years in Sexual Abuse Case
results.abstract: Dr. James Heaps had been convicted of five criminal counts in a case that cost the university hundreds of millions of dollars in settlements.

media.caption: James Heaps, a former gynecologist at U.C.L.A., has been sentenced to 11 years in prison for sexually abusing female patients over the course of a 35-year career.

results.adx_keywords: Folk Music;Pop and Rock Music;Black People;Race and Ethnicity;Movies;Actors and Actresses;Civil Rights Movement (1954-68);Deaths (Obituaries);Belafonte, Harry
results.title: Harry Belafonte, 96, Dies; Barrier-Breaking Singer, Actor and Activist
results.abstract: In the 1950s, when segregation was still widespread, his ascent to the upper echelon of show business was historic. But his primary focus was civil rights.

media.caption: Harry Belafonte was not the first Black entertainer to transcend racial boundaries, but none had made as much of a splash as he did. For a few years no one in music, Black or white, was bigger. Above, the singer in 1957.

results.adx_keywords: Books and Literature;Movies;Teenagers and Adolescence;Generation X;audio-neutral-informative;Blume, Judy;Lions Gate Entertainment Corporation;New York City
results.title: Why ‘Are You There, God? It’s Me, Margaret’ Still Matters
results.abstract: Judy Blume’s coming-of-age story finally hits the big screen this month. The book will always have a spotlight of its own.

media.caption: “My mother’s always telling me about when she was a girl,” Margaret tells us in the novel. “It’s supposed to make me feel that she understands everything.”

results.title: Stolen or Original? Hear Songs From 7 Landmark Copyright Cases.
results.abstract: Ed Sheeran is on trial, accused of borrowing from Marvin Gaye. Listen to the tracks at stake in lawsuits involving George Harrison, 2 Live Crew, Led Zeppelin and Katy Perry that may shape his case.

media.caption: The family of the soul star Marvin Gaye (left) sued Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams (right) over their song “Blurred Lines.” The case had a major impact on songwriting, and legal challenges to come.

results.title: Remains Found at Lake Mead Are Identified as Missing Las Vegas Man
results.abstract: Claude Russell Pensinger was 52 when he disappeared in 1998, the authorities said. Plunging water levels have played a role in the discoveries of other human remains at the lake since last year.

media.caption: So-called bathtub rings have been visible at Lake Mead since last year, signs of salts and minerals left behind on the canyon walls as the water has receded.

results.adx_keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks;Black People;Deaths (Obituaries);Meggett, Emily;Southern States (US)
results.title: Emily Meggett, Matriarch of Gullah Geechee Cuisine, Is Dead at 90
results.abstract: She never used a recipe in cooking, but she published a best-selling cookbook that documented the Gullah Geechee food of the coastal South.

media.caption: Emily Meggett at a book signing event at a Charleston, S.C., bookstore last year. She had never written down her recipes until she wrote her cookbook.
media.copyright: Nora Williams for The New York Times

results.byline: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Emily Schmall
results.title: A Giant Blob of Seaweed Is Heading to Florida
results.abstract: The mass, known as the great Atlantic Sargassum belt, is drifting toward the Gulf of Mexico. Scientists say seaweed is likely to come ashore by summer to create a rotting, stinking, scourge.

media.caption: A worker removing sargassum with machinery at a resort in Cancun, Mexico, last year.
